qas.question: By the late 60s, what term was synonymous with hard rock?
What heavy metal group introduced darker themes to the music?
What genre was an influence on extreme metal in the 1980s?
Hard rock is differentiated from heavy metal by containing more of an influence of what genre?
In heavy metal, riffs typically form what element of a song?
Which term was never used interchangeably with hard rock?
What did hard rock music change to keep it's identity?
What riffs were combined to create swing?
What band had a 1960s break through with an emphasis on darker themes?
Which two genres have never considered to have very much in common?

context: In the late 1960s, the term <a0_0><b5_0>heavy metal<b5_0/><a0_0/> was used interchangeably with hard rock, but gradually began to be used to describe music played with even more <b6_0>volume and intensity<b6_0/>. While hard rock maintained a <a3_0>bluesy<a3_0/> rock and roll identity, including some swing in the back beat and riffs that tended to outline chord progressions in their hooks, <b7_0>heavy metal's riffs<b7_0/> often functioned as <a4_0>stand-alone melodies<a4_0/> and had no swing in them. Heavy metal took on "darker" characteristics after <a1_0><b8_0>Black Sabbath<b8_0/><a1_0/>'s breakthrough at the beginning of the 1970s. In the 1980s it developed a number of subgenres, often termed extreme metal, some of which were influenced by <a2_0>hardcore punk<a2_0/>, and which further differentiated the two styles. Despite this differentiation, <b9_0>hard rock and heavy metal<b9_0/> have existed side by side, with bands frequently standing on the boundary of, or crossing between, the genres.
